claim: Advanced AI already multiplies scientific productivity (often 2–3×), and using AI to build better AI constitutes an early form of recursive self-improvement that could compress a decade of research into a year or even a month.
explanation: Evidence to date shows AI boosts productivity on specific research-related tasks, but typical gains are tens of percent, not “often 2–3×”: RCTs report 14% for customer support, ~40% faster professional writing, ~21% faster complex engineering tasks, and 56% faster on a single coding task. ([nber.org](https://www.nber.org/papers/w31161?utm_source=chatgpt.com), [pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/37440646/?utm_source=chatgpt.com), [arxiv.org](https://arxiv.org/abs/2410.12944?utm_source=chatgpt.com)) Field evidence in one materials-science lab found 44% more discoveries (with near-doubling only among top performers), and observational work links AI adoption to more papers and citations, but these results are uneven and not yet generalizable across science. ([arxiv.org](https://arxiv.org/abs/2412.17866?utm_source=chatgpt.com)) AI is used to help build better AI (e.g., AlphaDev, self-refinement/distillation), yet claims that such “recursive self‑improvement” can compress a decade of research into a year or month remain speculative and unvalidated; prominent analyses urge caution. ([deepmind.google](https://deepmind.google/discover/blog/alphadev-discovers-faster-sorting-algorithms/?utm_source=chatgpt.com), [arxiv.org](https://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17651?utm_source=chatgpt.com), [newyorker.com](https://www.newyorker.com/culture/open-questions/two-paths-for-ai?utm_source=chatgpt.com))
